quote: Chief Medical Officer's Log:   Stardate 52645.7. Colonel Kira   and Garak have brought Odo back   to the station for treatment.
However, despite my best efforts,   I have yet to make any progress   in finding a cure for the   changeling disease.
How long do I have?
I can't be sure.
You can make an educated guess.
Yes... but first, I'm going to   try to slow down the progress of   the disease with a series of   nadion bursts combined with --
I want a time-frame, Doctor.
A week. With the nadion therapy,   maybe two.
Thank you. I want to see Kira   now.
Let me emphasize again, that I   have not given up hope and it's   very important that you not give   up either.
Understood. Now, let me see   Kira.
How do you feel?
Better.
Good.
You should be going soon.
I'm not going anywhere. Garak   and Damar can lead the rebellion   without me.
Damar needs someone who's   actually fought with a resistance   movement. That's you, not Garak.
I'm not leaving until I know   you're going to be --
I want you to leave.
Why?
You watched Bariel die in this   very room and I know how that's   haunted you. I don't want your   last memory of me to be...   witnessing my death.
Shouldn't that be my choice?
Maybe it should. Maybe I'm being   selfish telling you all the   things I want, but... I don't   want the last thing I see to be a   look of pain in your eyes.
You'd be surprised how well I can   hide my feelings when I need to.
Not from me. You have to go,   Nerys.
All right.
I can't be a very pleasant sight.
I don't care how you look.
There's so much to say... I don't   know where to start...
Just say you love me. That's all   I've ever cared about. Then give   me your smile... and go.
I love you, Odo.
I love you, Nerys.
... so I forwarded the schematics   of the Breen weapon to Starfleet   Engineering. They should have a   preliminary --
Garak and I should be getting   underway.
The commander is correct. We   have to evade several Jem'Hadar   patrols in order to reach Damar's   base. If we wait too long, they   might alter their patrol routes.
I see.
No, sir. I think we have all the   data we need.
Well, then.
(without looking    back)   Julian...
I'll do everything I can.
Is there anything I can do to   help? Any additional resources   from Starfleet Medical that you   might want?
No, sir. At this point, I have   everything I need.
We should tell you that research   isn't the only avenue we're   pursuing.
Miles...
He needs to know.
Let me settle that. Whatever's   going on, I want to know right   now.
We're... trying to lure someone   from Section Thirty-one to the   station.
Section Thirty-one? What do they   have to do with this?
We believe they're responsible   for infecting Odo in the first   place.
What!
We think Odo was infected three   years ago when he was supposedly   undergoing tests at Starfleet   Headquarters.
Evidently, Section Thirty-one   hoped that Odo would transmit the   disease to the others when he   linked with them.
Genocide.       Committed by people who call   themselves Federation citizens...       Why didn't you tell me about this   earlier?
We felt that if we did --
The chief wanted to tell you, but   as senior officer, I ordered him   not to. It's my fault.
I'm still waiting for an answer   to my question.

We have no proof. Besides... I   knew that if we told you what we   suspected, you'd feel an   obligation to report it to   Starfleet Command. And once you   did, Section Thirty-one would   most likely find out that we were   onto them and go even deeper into   hiding.
What difference does that make?

There came a point where I had to   admit that my research was going   nowhere. I wasn't going to find   a cure in the lab. So, the chief   and I decided to look for it in   Section Thirty-one itself. A   few days ago, I sent a false   message to Starfleet Medical   announcing that I had found a   cure.
The idea is that when Thirty-one   hears about it, they'll want to   destroy Julian's research to   prevent it from falling into the   Dominion's hands.
So you're trying to lure one of   their operatives to the station.   Okay, let's say it works. What   then?
We capture him, or her, and then   try to find out what they know   about the disease, who's   involved, and maybe even where to   find the cure.
And how do you propose to do   that? I doubt they'll be very   cooperative.
I've... managed to get my hands   on a Romulan memory scanner.
Since they're illegal in the   Federation, I'll assume that's   another reason why you didn't   come to me.
Yes, sir.
Setting aside the legal and   ethical issues involved... this   still seems like a long shot.
It is. But I'm afraid it may be   the only shot Odo has.
I just wanted to... come by to   see how you're doing...
I hear the prognosis is... well...

There's something you might like   to know, before...       Something we've never talked   about... even though I'm sure   it's always been... in the back   of our minds...       It has to do with the... Tilavan   art theft. I think I know who   stole the holo-sculptures.
Tell me.
On second thought... why bother?
What?
It's not like you're in any shape   to do something about it. Forget   I brought it up.
I've spent nine years working on   that case
I know. That's why it's such a   shame that you won't have time to   close it before you...
You're going to tell me exactly   what you know and you're going to   do it right now.
Oh. Suddenly you're not so sick   after all. You want to crack the   case? Then stop malingering and   get back to work. When you do,   you know where to find me.
Can't sleep?
No.
How'd you get in?
The lock's not that complex.       What are you doing up?
I was running another power test   on the Breen weapon.
I was trying to read, but I found   myself reading the same page over   and over again.
What are you reading?
"It was the best of times, it was   the worst of times... "
A Tale of Two Cities. My   mother's favorite book....
I'm enjoying it so far. But   tonight my mind was elsewhere...
Odo?

Section Thirty-one... I kept   thinking about how many people   had to be involved in the   conspiracy to infect Odo with the   disease. Doctors... security   officers... admirals... computer   experts... clerks...       I came up with at least seventy-   three people.
I was afraid you were going to   say seventy thousand.
This organization -- this thing   that's slithered its way into the   heart of the Federation -- it has   to be destroyed.
You'll get no argument from me.       But for now, let's stay focused   on curing Odo. That's the   priority.
Right.
I think I've had enough. You?
Sure.
But sleep lightly. Section   Thirty-one may still take the   bait and show up.
I'll be ready.
Lights.
Hello, doctor.
I didn't think I'd ever see you   again.
I have another assignment for   you.
Really? What a coincidence. I   have an assignment for you.
I take it I'm supposed to feel   shocked and humbled by your   ingenuity.
Frankly, I don't care how you   feel.       Bashir to O'Brien.
Yeah... ?
Mister Sloan is here, Miles.   I've got him in the containment   field.
I'm on my way.
Good. Bashir out.
What is it you want, Doctor?
Why the same thing you want --   the cure to the disease.
What are you talking about? You   already have the cure.       No, you don't. Your message to   Starfleet Medical... was just   bait.
Which I'm happy to see that you   swallowed.
So now you've got me. What good do   you think will come of this?   Turning me over to Starfleet   Security will be a waste of time.   You don't have a shred of evidence.
I'm not interested in turning you   over to anyone.
Hello, again.
Shooting an unarmed man? That's   a little ungallant of you, isn't   it?
Somehow, I didn't think you'd   walk in here of your own   volition.
You're probably right.
Hello, Chief. How's the family?   Everyone okay at home?
What's that supposed to mean?
Nothing. I'd just hate to see   anything happen to them...
Don't listen to him, Chief. He's   playing games with you.
Easy for him to say, he doesn't   have a wife and children to worry   about. But, trust me, Chief, if   something were to happen to me --
What? They'll be killed? I'm   disappointed in you, Sloan. You   don't usually wield such a blunt   instrument.
So am I supposed to guess what's   going on or do I lie here in   "terror" waiting for you to tell   me?
I told you. I want the cure to   Odo's disease and you're going to   help me find it.
What makes you think I know   anything about it?

You came here because you thought   I'd discovered the cure and you   wanted to destroy it. But first   you'd have to find it in my lab.   And how would you do that unless   you knew exactly what you were   looking for?
You'd never do anything so...   sloppy. You prefer surgical   precision. You came here to   destroy the cure, which means   somewhere in that brain of yours   is the information I want.
You don't really expect me to   tell you.
Oh, I suspect you'll resist to   the bitter end.
We're ready.
Recognize these? Romulan mind   probes. Not the most pleasant   devices, but very efficient.
They're also illegal in the   Federation.
I hope you appreciate the irony   of that statement.
I'm telling you, I don't know   anything about the cure.
Then I won't find anything, will   I?
When Sisko finds out what you're   doing he'll --
The captain already knows what   we're doing, Sloan. And he's   given us his full support.
I can't let you have the cure,   Julian. Too much is at stake.
I'm afraid the choice is no   longer yours.

I misread you. I thought you   were just a misguided idealist.   But you're a dangerous man.   People like you would destroy the   Federation if given a chance...   but fortunately there are people   like me who will die to protect   it.
Damn!
What's going on?
He activated a neuro-depolarizing   device in his brain.
He's trying to kill himself!       I've got to stabilize him before   he suffers irreversible damage!
If he dies...
... The cure for Odo dies with   him...
What's the verdict?
Well, he's stable... for now.   But the neuro-depolarizer has   damaged his brain. Even with   full life support, his higher   cortical functions are going to   fail within the next hour.
He committed suicide to keep us   from finding the cure.
We had him cornered and he knew   it. He couldn't let one of   Section Thirty-one's darkest   secrets get away from him.
The frustrating thing is that the   cure is still in there,   somewhere...
I know this sounds a little...   morbid, but... what if you used   the Romulan mental probes now?
Sloan's memory pathways have been   scrambled -- probably to prevent   anyone from doing exactly what   you proposed.
I'm not going to let you win this   one, Sloan. There has to be a   way to retrieve that data...
Maybe we should just let him die   in peace...
Miles, I need a multitronic   engrammatic interpreter.
Or maybe I'll get you a   multitronic engrammatic   interpreter...
This is crazy.
It'll work, Miles.
You've got me re-routing so many   power relays and transfer coils   that I can't guarantee any of   this will work without running a   series of diagnostics.
I've already done the diagnostics   in my head.
... and the neural interface will   then provide a basic pattern to   my hippocampal nuclei.
I give up. You've explained it   three times now and I still don't   understand.
You just have to trust me, Miles.   I know what I'm doing.
But even if you can link your   mind to Sloan's, how are you   going to find the cure?

The entire experience will be   processed into images and sounds   that my conscious mind can   understand. In essence, I'll see   the neuronal pathways of his   brain as literal pathways or   streets or corridors or   something.
And you'll just... wander along   these streets looking for a box   labeled "the cure?"
As strange as it sounds, it might   be just that simple. On the   other hand, the experience could   be much more surrealistic... I   could find myself caught up in   memories of Sloan's childhood.
Will he be... aware of what   you're doing?
I won't know that until I'm   there. We don't know what the   conscious mind can perceive when   it's this close to brain death.
How will you get out?

One of the advantages to being   genetically enhanced is the   ability to control your own vital   signs. When I've found the cure   and I want to leave, I'll send my   hypothalamus a signal to raise my   blood pressure forty percent.   When that happens, the equipment   will automatically break the   link.
What if you get disoriented or...   lost in some nightmare of Sloan's   and then he dies?
Worst case scenario... I die with   him. But I think the risk is   manageable.
I'm going with you.
What?
You heard me. And it's not open
You just don't want to be here   when Captain Sisko finds out what   we're doing.
That too.
Well... I guess we better get   another bed.
How long do we have?
Sloan's brain will die in about   forty-three minutes. We have   that long to get in, find the   cure and get out.
The analyzer is on-line. Ready?
No. But let's do it anyway.
Julian... ?
Hello, Miles...
Why are we in a turbolift... ?
I'm not sure...
I don't remember getting in   here... are we--
We're in Sloan's mind.    (off his confused    look)   Remember?
Sloan. Right. But we're really   still... in the lab.
Yes. This... turbolift is just   an abstraction.
So... where're we going?
I don't know, but we're not
Maybe this wasn't such a good   idea after all...
Aren't you glad you came along?
Wouldn't have missed it for the   world.
What do you think?
I think we stopped.
Are you sure?
Either that... or we're falling   very, very slowly.
(re: their grips on    the railing)   Then we can let go.
No reason not to.
Well?
You first.
Why me? This little trip wasn't   my idea.
All right, we'll let go together.
On three.
One, two... three.
See? Nothing to worry about.
I wasn't worried.
Now what?
Good question.
Doctor! Chief O'Brien. Welcome.   You don't know how happy I am to   see you.
I'm glad you're happy, Sloan.   Now tell us how to cure Odo and   we can all be happy.
Believe me, Doctor -- nothing   would give me greater pleasure.   But first, there are a few people   I'd like you to meet.
Look, Sloan -- we're a little   pressed for time.
But you just arrived.    (thinking it    through)   I see. You're afraid that if I   die while you're still in here...   you'll die, too.       We can't let that happen, can we?   We'd better hurry.
We're not going anywhere until   you give us the cure.
All right. If you insist. It's   a simple nucleotide marking   sequence -- radodine...
lidestolinine, asporanine,   adenine...
You mind repeating that?
We don't have time for games,   Sloan.
Believe me, I want to tell you   everything you need to know.
Then tell us.
Because I can't.       lidestolinine, asporanine,   adenine... You see?       I suppose there's a part of me   that doesn't want to tell you --   not until you come with me to the   wardroom.
Maybe we should do as he says.
It could be a trap.
I don't blame you for being   suspicious, doctor -- but if you   want the cure, you're going to   have to trust me.       The clock is ticking.
He's right about that.
Follow me.
Relax, doctor. I'm the one   dying, not you.
Why Deep Space Nine?
Excuse me?
I'm just wondering why the inside   of your head looks like our space   station?
I wanted to make you feel at   home. Comfortable.
Why?
Everyone... if I can have your   attention, please.    (re: Bashir and    O'Brien)   Now that we're all here... I hope   you'll forgive me if I take a   moment to say a few words.

As I stand here, reunited with my   friends and family for one last   time... I want you -- the people   I love -- to know just how sorry   I am for all the pain I've caused   you. I dedicated my life to the   preservation and protection of   the Federation. This duty, which   I carried out to the best of my   ability, took precedence over   everything else... my parents, my   wife, my children...       I lived in a world of secrets.   Of sabotage and deceit. I spent   so much time erasing my   movements, covering my tracks...   and now that I look back at my   life, I find... nothing. It's as   if I never really existed. I   cheated you all out of being in   my life. And what's more, I   cheated myself as well.       I know a simple apology won't   change that. Still, I feel the   need to apologize anyway.
No tears, please. My death isn't   a tragedy, it's a celebration.   In death, I can finally step out   of the shadows and prove to   myself that I existed. That I   lived.
Luther -- that was beautiful.
Gentlemen, I'd like you to meet   my wife -- Jessica. This is   Doctor Bashir and Chief O'Brien --       If it weren't for them, I   wouldn't be here.
(to Bashir and    O'Brien)   I can't thank you enough for all   you've done for Luther... and for   me. Frankly, being married to   him was a living hell. But   thanks to you, that's all   changed.
Congratulations.

Doctor, you've been a beacon of   light to me. You're living proof   that ideology is a poor   substitute for kindness and   decency and that at the end of   the day, it's our actions, not   our beliefs, that define who we   are... what we are.
I'm glad I could help. Now, if   you don't mind...
You want me to tell you how to   cure Odo. Gladly, doctor.       My dear -- I need that PADD I   gave you for safekeeping.
I know I have it somewhere.
Here it is.
Thanks, muffin.       Here you go, Doctor --
I'm sorry, doctor, but I can't   let you have that.
Julian...
Don't look at me for an   explanation.
I knew it.
Knew what?
That this wasn't going to be   easy.
Mind telling me what going on?

I have no idea. The chief was   supposed to fix my sonic shower   this morning, but he never showed   up. I asked the computer where   he was, and when I came in...   this is what I found.       Any idea who that is?
Sloan. He works for Section   Thirty-one.
Then I'd guess this isn't some   kind of obscure meditation   therapy.
Definitely not.       Sisko to Infirmary.
Infirmary.
I need a medical team in Science   Lab Four, right away.
I wish I knew how long we've been   in here.
Twenty-three minutes, eleven seconds.
Show off.
That leaves us less than twenty   minutes to find a cure and get out.
Locked, just like the others.   For all we know, Sloan could be   hiding in any one of these rooms.   Or he could've taken that turn-   off we passed.
What's your point, Miles?
We're not going to find him unless   he wants to be found -- after all,   we're on his playing field.
Stop right there.
Now what?
You're in a restricted area.
I thought we were in the   cerebellum.
We're looking for Sloan.
Mister Sloan is not available at   the moment.
Dammit -- we don't have time for   this. We need to speak to Sloan!
You shot him!
That really hurts!
He's a threat to the Federation.
You all right?
Do I look all right?
It doesn't make sense... if none   of this is real, how come it   hurts so much?
Sloan's mind could be sending   sensory stimuli into ours,   causing us to experience pain,   just as we would if we'd really   been shot... of course, that's   just a theory.
Makes sense to me. Maybe this is
I can't...
Why not?
I just tried the hypothalamic   feedback loop... I think I'm too   weak...
What do you mean you're too weak?   Julian -- we have to get out of   here!
I know that! But I've been shot --   at least my body thinks I've been   shot.
(with growing    frustration)   I don't believe this.
I'm sorry.
I guess this is it then...
Looks that way.
I should've left Keiko a note...   told her what we were planning.
Why worry her?
I want her and the kids to   understand why I had to do   this...
She'll understand, Miles. She'll   know you did it for me.
That's what's going to hurt her   most of all. She always said I   liked you better than her.
That's ridiculous.       Well, maybe a little.
What, are you crazy? She's my   wife. I love her.
Of course you love her. But   maybe she's right. Maybe you   like me more.
I do not!
You spend more time with me.
We work together.
More than that; we have a lot in   common.
Julian -- you're starting to   annoy me.
Racquetball, darts, Vic's lounge,   the Alamo... need I go on?
(shoring up his    resolve)   I love my wife.
And I love Ezri.
You do?
Passionately.       At least I think I do.
Have you told her?
Not yet, but I will.
When?
When I'm ready. But that's not   the point. I love her -- but I   like you more.       You see? I can admit it.
Well, I love my wife.
Miles... what's that?
My God, it's the tunnel!
What tunnel?
You know the tunnel -- to the   Great Beyond!
You're right. I must say I'm a   bit disappointed... I was hoping   for something a little more...   elaborate.
No. No. Come on Julian, we   can't let it end like this   sitting here, accepting death.   On your feet, man!
Let's check one more door.
What's the point?
The point is to die like men --   like Travis and Crockett. Doing   our duty right up until the end.
Like Travis and Crockett...
One more door...
Doctor Bashir's regaining   consciousness, captain.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: How's Miles?
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I'm fine.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Did you get the information you   were looking for?
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I'm afraid not.       We have to go back in...
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: That would not be wise, Doctor.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Sloan's dying. We can't risk   losing you as well.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Sloan's dying. We can't risk   losing you as well.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: He can't die. Not yet!
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Cordrazine. Ten milligrams.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: His alpha waves are attenuating.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Cortical stimulator.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: You're not getting away from me   that easily, Sloan.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Amplify the resonance frequency   ten percent.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: No response. His neurosynaptic   activity is failing.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I can see that. Fifteen   milligrams neurotropan.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Come on, Sloan. Come on back.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Complete neural failure.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: No!
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: He's dead, Doctor.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: It's over, Julian. He's gone...
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: And so's any hope of curing Odo.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: ... I wish I had better news. I'm   sorry.
I understand, doctor. You've   done all you could -- more than I   would've thought possible and I   appreciate it.
Is there anything I can do to   make you more comfortable?
Thank you, but right now I simply   want to be alone.
Of course.
How'd he take it?
Better than I would.
I need some sleep. So do you.
Look, Julian --
I know -- I did all I could.       It's small comfort.
"It was the best of times... "
"... it was the worst of times."
It's the first line of the book.
That's right. So why is it on   page two hundred and ninety-four?
Must be a misprint... the entire   book starts over again.
It can't be. Ezri loaned it to   me -- it used to be Jadzia's and   I know for a fact that she read   it.
You and Ezri are exchanging   books?
Forget about that. Don't you see   what's going on?
She's playing a practical joke.
No. It's Sloan. We're still   inside his mind.
What? These are my quarters --   Keiko's sleeping in the other   room.
No, she's not. Sloan is drawing   on our memories... making us   think we're back on the station.   That's why the book is   incomplete... because I hadn't   finished reading it.
And because you didn't know what   happened after page two-ninety-   four...
He couldn't fill in the rest of   the story.
He's trying to keep us from   looking for the cure.
Which means we must've been very   close to finding it.
The door -- the one we were about   to open when we woke up --the   cure must be in there.
What's going on?
Sloan's dying. His mind's   shutting down. We're running out   of time.
This is it!
Are you sure?
I can tell.
Sloan?
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Welcome to Section Thirty-one,   Gentlemen...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: You know what we're here for.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: You don't really expect me to   help you...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: You sure you want to throw that   one away... ?
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: I'm looking for medical   information, not surveillance   reports...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: That's not just any report...   it's on Garish Inyo.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Former President Inyo?
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: The one and only.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: My God... Thirty-one had a man   inside his cabinet...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Just one of the little nuggets   lying around in this... once-tidy   room. You'd be amazed at what   you could find in here.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Don't let him distract you.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Current operations on Chronos...   Chancellor Martok would love to   get his hands on this...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Julian!
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Radodine, lidestolinine,   asporanine, adenine...       This is it.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: I think it's time to get out of   here.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Hold on a moment.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: What for?
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: These files contain all of   Sloan's memories of Section   Thirty-one.       With this information... we could   destroy the entire organization.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: That'll have to wait.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: It's not that simple, Chief.   There's no building... no room   like this in the real world.   Section Thirty-one has no   headquarters. These files...   they exist only in the minds of a   very select group of people. I   happen to be one of them...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: If you really want to destroy   Section Thirty-one... it's now or   never.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: He's right. This is a once in a   lifetime opportunity, Miles. We   can't pass it up.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Julian!
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Leave me alone --
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Listen to me -- he's trying to   keep us here. He wants us to die   with him. And if we die -- Odo   dies too!
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: All my secrets are yours for the   taking, doctor... if you want   them badly enough.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Odo needs you, Julian. He's   counting on you.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: You're making a terrible mistake,   doctor...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: I don't think so.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Julian, are you with us?
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Ezri... you look beautiful.
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Were you able to find the cure?
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I think so, but there's only one   way to know for sure...
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Sloan?
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: He died about two minutes ago...   Almost took you with him.
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Julian, next time you take a trip   into someone's mind... you're   going alone.
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Right.
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I should warn you... you might   feel some discomfort.
If you mean it's going to be   painful, just say so.
It's going to be painful.
All right then. Go ahead.
How long before Odo's up and   around?
His morphogenic matrix needs time   to heal. He should be his old   self again in a few days.
I knew Quark was hoarding a   bottle of the good stuff in here   somewhere.
This is older than I am.
What?
I can't believe I'm drinking with   a child.
To aging gracefully?
Very funny.       To Odo.
Wow.
Wow is right.
Let me ask you something... if   you'd had time to read more of   the data in Sloan's mind... you   really think we could've brought   down Section Thirty-one?
We'll never know, will we? One   thing's for sure -- Sloan knew it was   the perfect bait... that I wouldn't   be able to resist it. Luckily he   failed to consider one thing...
What's that?
You.       To Miles Edward O'Brien.
To friendship.
To friendship.
We already did that.
Let's do it again.
I've got to get home. Keiko's   holding dinner for me.
This late?
She's a helluva woman.
That's why you love her.
That's right. That's why I love   her.
You wanna come?
Sure.
